pullRequest.body:
Defines `List.rget`, which returns the n-th element from the right hand-side of a list, and proves some lemmata about it, including relations to rdrop and rtake.
Adds lemmata to Data.List.DropRight.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [386fc5ad9e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18767/commits/386fc5ad9e253917e9974bf8a8f9a21bc8d70c64)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Data.List.GetRight`|280|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ length_rtake`
`+ rdrop_append_rtake`
`+ rget`
`+ rget_append_right`
`+ rget_cons_eq_self`
`+ rget_cons_length`
`+ rget_cons_rtake`
`+ rget_singleton`
`+ rget_suffix`
`+ rtake_cons_eq_self_of_le_length`
`+ rtake_length_le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
The "awaiting review" label says "don't use", so I didn't. Hope I'm doing this right.
It says the build is failing because of `rtake_nil`, which I didn't modify :sweat_smile:
Notice there is a linter error: you will need to remove the `@[simp]` annotation from the lemma that `simp` can already prove.
Could you say something about the motivation for this?
I might be wrong but isn't `*Right` preferable to `r*`? (I don't think this matters much.)

I don't understand the current build error, which seems to be due to git, which I'm not all too familiar wit. I didn't `git pull`, should I have ?

@kim-em 

- changed `rget_append` to `rget_append_right`
- Used `Fin.castLE` whenever posssible
- About the simp-build-error, which was from the previous build error, which stated
```
/- The `simpNF` linter reports:
SOME SIMP LEMMAS ARE NOT IN SIMP-NORMAL FORM.
see note [simp-normal form] for tips how to debug this.
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/notes.html#simp-normal%20form -/
-- Mathlib.Data.List.DropRight
Error: ././././Mathlib/Data/List/DropRight.lean:65:1: error: @List.rtake_nil simp can prove this:
  by simp only [@List.length_nil, @zero_le, @List.rtake_length_le]
One of the lemmas above could be a duplicate.
If that's not the case try reordering lemmas or adding @[priority].
```
The error refers to a lemma in the `DropRight` file which I didn't modify, so I don't understand the error.

- Motivation: In the formalism for games, there is the notion of a history of moves, which is a list of elements representing the moves. For example, strategies are functions taking a given history and returning the next move to play. Then, the n-th element from the right corresponds to the move played on turn n+1 (turn 0 corresponds to an empty history).
Though I believe it may be useful in other contexts too to get elements of a list from the right: say if the list is a stack of sorts, where we don't pop elements and we want to consider the n-th element added.


@fgdorais 
I chose the name to be coherent with `rtake` and `rdrop` (and the file name is inspired by the file `DropRight`), but I can see how this breakes the pattern of `get!`, `getD`, ...,  so I'm fine with any name change.

> I don't understand the current build error, which seems to be due to git, which I'm not all too familiar wit. I didn't `git pull`, should I have ?

Can you please merge master? It should then disappear automatically
@fgdorais, @kim-em, do you have quick thoughts here?

```suggestion
  l.get t.rev
```
works and is so short that I wonder whether you actually need this definition.

Nice :+1:
There are comments on performance in the `DropRight` file, that suggest that performance matters, in which case reversing the list is a bit costly. On the other hand, your approach should make lemmata easier to prove, as we shouldn't get into trouble with the proofs for `Fin` all the time.
I'm fine with reimplementing the file with Yael's definition. Still think there should be API for taking elements from the right, even if proofs are trivial.

> There are comments on performance in the `DropRight` file, that suggest that performance matters, in which case reversing the list is a bit costly

Note that in my suggestion we are not reversing the list, but rather the index!
:sweat: off to a good start, lol. I'll implement the change :+1:
Done :+1:
This should be called `rget_append_right`, as it is not a complete description of `rget` applied to an `append` (which would have an `if` statement).
I'd prefer that for all these lemmas we don't break about the `Fin` and put it back together, but instead use e.g. `Fin.cast` and `Fin.castLE`.

pullRequest.title: feat: `List.rget` and related lemmata
